contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person | name = William Gates | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1971|12|28}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | residence = | nationality = American | ethnicity = African-American | alma_mater = [[Marquette University]] | parents = }} '''William Gates''' (born December 28, 1971 in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]<ref name="#22">{{cite web|url=http://wiki.muscoop.com/doku.php/men_s_basketball/william_gates|title=William Gates #22 Biography|work=muscoop.com}}</ref>) is an American retired high school and [[college basketball]] player, and a subject of the 1994 [[Kartemquin Films]] documentary film ''[[Hoop Dreams]]''. ==Biography== Gates was a teenager from the [[Cabrini–Green]] housing projects. He and [[Arthur Agee]], from [[West Garfield Park]], hoped to hone their [[basketball]] talent into professional careers with the [[NBA]]. The documentary Hoop Dreams followed them through their recruitment by [[St. Joseph High School (Westchester, Illinois)|St. Joseph High School]]. During high school, he worked hard both to improve his basketball skills and his academics to the best of his ability, though he initially struggled with a low reading level. He struggled to get the required score of an 18 on the [[ACT (examination)|ACT exam]] needed to earn a scholarship at [[Marquette University]], but finally managed a 17.5 aggregate score, which was rounded up to 18. At St. Joseph, Gates suffered a knee injury which limited his playing and recruitment offers. After he had a kid and left Marquette, with out graduating, he went to Loyola University in Chicago where he still did not graduate. He became a community liaison to the new development in Cabri-Green. Gates would go on to give back to the community as senior pastor at Living Faith Community Center in [[Cabrini-Green|Cabrini–Green]], where he works at the Kids' Club. In 2001, Gates worked out with NBA star [[Michael Jordan]] in preparation for Jordan's comeback and was offered a tryout with the [[Washington Wizards]], but injured his foot. His brother, Curtis Gates, also seen in the film, was murdered on September 10, 2001.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A27976-2004Jul4_4.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Looking Back At Broken 'Dreams' | date=5 July 2004}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0309637|name=William Gates}} *[http://gomarquette.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/061603aaa.html All-Time Men's Basketball Letterwinners through June 2003] – Marquette Athletics *[http://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A27976-2004Jul4?language=printer Looking Back At Broken 'Dreams'] – washingtonpost.com {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Authority control|VIAF=61187694}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Gates, William | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American basketball player | DATE OF BIRTH = 28 December 1978 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gates, William}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:African-American basketball players]] [[Category:Basketball players from Illinois]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Marquette Golden Eagles men's basketball players]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Chicago, Illinois]] {{1970s-US-basketball-bio-stub}} {{US-Christian-clergy-stub}}
